Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Dialing in on the proton: Understanding the role of the proton in photo-induced, proton-coupled electron transfer using tunable model systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Research at Undergraduate Institutions (RUI) project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Elizabeth R. Young of the Department of Chemistry at Amherst College is studying electron transfer in model molecular systems. These models are inspired by biological systems, specifically proteins, which carry out reactions necessary for life very efficiently. Results of this research could lead to the development of more energy efficient reactions, including splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen for energy storage, nitrogen fixation for agriculture and carbon dioxide reduction to decrease greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Undergraduate students carry out the research, directly participating in each phase of the research projects: experimental design, physical evaluation, characterization, data analysis and scientific writing. Students are trained in a broad range of scientific techniques and learn cutting-edge research. Additionally, this project enhances the research infrastructure in the Pioneer Valley of Massachusetts.

Proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) drives numerous critical reactions in natural systems, including the light-harvesting reactions of photosynthesis. This project explores several features in the mechanistic study of PCET. The interplay between electron transfer driving force and the proton transfer ability of acid groups in a series of donor and acceptor systems is studied, in order to provide direct insight into how hydrogen-bonded interfaces modulate electron transfer. Specific questions to be answered include: For which electron transfer driving force ranges does the proton transfer ability make a substantial difference in the observed rates? Does the ability of a proton within the interface result in significant modulation in the electron transfer rate between the same donor and acceptor moieties? Does the mode of supramolecular donor-acceptor assembly have a significant impact on coupling and electron transfer rates? These mechanistic studies of PCET provide important insights into how light could be used to initiate chemical reactions that are facilitated by the concerted movement of protons and electrons.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemists are eager to identify new approaches to harness the power of the sun to drive chemical reactions. One promising area for research focuses on developing systems modeled on naturally-occurring chemical reactions, in which electrons and protons are exchanged through a coordinated movement together along a pathway. This “coupled” electron-proton process, known as proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET), plays a critical role in small molecule activation, and is important for other energy conversion reactions in proteins and enzymes, including energy transduction, charge transport and catalysis. Industrial processes already employ small molecule activation reactions, such as water splitting, nitrogen fixation and carbon dioxide reduction. Learning how to leverage the benefits of low-energy intermediates accessible through PCET that are driven by excited states will enable scientists to create more favorable energetic and chemical conditions for engineering chemical transformations that draw on the sun’s energy. PCET model systems to date have yet to incorporate a systematic method for controlling proton transfer driving forces and donor-acceptor coupling. 

 

This research project aimed to advance the development of new excited-state driven PCET model systems by investigating the parameters that control the proton motion. Indeed, the first system studied under this project utilized a ruthenium polypyridal complex, ruthenium trisbipyridine (Ru(bpy)32+) an excellent photo-oxidant, towards this end. A photo-oxidant is a molecule that upon absorption of light grabs an electron from other molecules, thereby initiating a chemical reaction. In these studies the other molecules were a series of ferrocene molecules synthesized with a variety of chemical functionalities. The various functionalities on the ferrocene molecules allowed the thermodynamic properties of the ferrocene to be tuned so that the researchers could measure the influence of various protonation states and charges on the resulting kinetics and mechanism of the interaction.  

 

In a first set of studies, researchers found that the quenching rate between Ru(bpy)32+ and the ferrocene molecules was dependent on pH conditions when the ferrocene derivative (ferrocenyl-amidinium, Fc–am) contained an acid functionality but did not depend on pH in the absence of a protonic group (ferrocenyl-methyl ammonium, Fc–mam). These results show that the presence (or absence) of a proton modulates quenching rates between the Ru(bpy)32+ and the ferrocene molecules. Further, transient absorption spectroscopy revealed that, surprisingly, the mechanism of interaction between Ru(bpy)32+ and Fc–am was modulated by pH, switching from energy transfer at low pH conditions when Fc–am is protonated to electron transfer at high pH conditions when Fc–am is deprotonated. A simple driving force dependence did not justify the mechanistic switch. These results are the first of their kind and provide compelling evidence that there is more at play in electron transfer and the factors that govern it than what is fully explained by the Marcus Theory for electron transfer.

 

In a second set of studies, the library of ferrocene molecules was expanded.  Appending various functional groups onto the cyclopentadienyl ring of ferrocene altered the chemical properties of the ferrocene moieties, by tuning the oxidation potentials and the charge on the molecule. Further, the reaction was performed in various solvents, including anhydrous acetonitrile, dimethylformamide, dimethyl sulfoxide, and water (pH 10), which allowed for further changes to the chemical system. Researchers characterized the quenching mechanism as either energy transfer or electron transfer. Marcus Theory fitting and driving force calculations were utilized to assign mechanisms for the quenching interactions and to identify trends in the observed reaction. Interestingly, the quenching mechanism was determined primarily by electrostatic considerations. If the ferrocene moiety was positively charged, energy transfer occurred thereby avoiding a more highly charged electron transfer products. If, however, the ferrocene donor was neutral or negatively charged, electron transfer was observed. These studies add valuable insight to interactions between molecules in which energy or electron transfer are both viable interaction mechanisms. Such system include a wide range of biological systems involved in chemical power conversion and host of engineered systems involving sensing and energy capture and storage. 

 

Funds for this project provided support to the multi-user transient absorption laser facility headed by the PI that enhanced the research infrastructure in the Pioneer Valley. Additionally, this project directly supported undergraduate students who carried out the proposed research. In the one year of funding provided under this grant, two undergraduate students attended the national meeting of the American Chemical Society, providing them with insight into the vast field of chemical research and industry. These types experiences afford students confidence that helped them make future plans for graduate school. The experiences and training students received by carrying out independent, self-directed research pre-dispose them to become rich, careful thinkers, who are effective public advocates for the benefit of science and exploratory research.
